0.28.text:
I think one of the first things
I noticed about your work...

5.44.text: I need to tell a brief...

6.64.text:
I was in London soon after
James Blake's...

10.48.text:
his sort of, breakthrough hit
came through...

13.92.text:
And I was talking to my friend, I was like,
what an interesting progression,

16.80.text: because he went from doing sort of like

22.00.text:
and then started putting in his voice as
kind of a process thing...

26.40.text:
and then suddenly it's like this
pop territory, so moving from...

30.12.text:
a sort of invisibility, an honest producer,
into like, and I said it to a journalist friend

35.48.text:
and he was like "oh, yeah.

38.12.text:
and "he's very handsome" and
he was like, it's a very commercial move

43.36.text: But what I noticed about your work

46.92.text:
had this similar, kind of starting off...
at least in what reached me...

52.60.text:
as being very abstracted, and then
slowly ideas, a voice and invisibility...

58.12.text:
went into it in a way that didn't feel like it

61.32.text:

65.68.text:
and sort of, statement
that you were making.

69.24.text:
but it was following your sounds for like
two years or so.

73.36.text:
And so I'm just kind curious about how
you think about that; these longer arks...

78.24.text:
when people are following your work,
and like you said, y'know...

80.92.text:
like what is... maybe singing
is a very vulnerable thing for you, but...

85.64.text:
Yeah, I think that's
a really interesting point.

I think there's a lot of factors that went
into that

91.52.text:
I mean, you know, one of them
is just like what I was interested in,

94.88.text:
and investigating,
kind of like pushed me.

97.92.text:
Especially with Chorus a little bit

101.72.text:
having to find that vulnerable place

105.44.text:
So there's, just some of that, y'know,
just like thematically

108.12.text: kind of pushed me in that way, but also...

110.84.text:
Y'know, just my own comfort level...
I still don't think of myself as a vocalist

116.04.text:
or, like a pop singer or anything like that,
you know...

119.28.text:
that's never really
how I've perceived myself.

121.20.text:
So it was always just...
it's been this kind of evolution of like...

124.52.text:
how can I push myself to different places
where I'm still...

128.32.text:
where I'm uncomfortable but it's still me,
where I'm, y'know, challenging myself.

132.24.text:
So I think it's partly personal,
and I think it's also partly cultural;

135.48.text:
I think that the landscape has changed
from when I started...

139.44.text:
from when Movement came out to today,
I feel like people are...

143.96.text:
people have shifted their perspective,
people are more open to things.

148.44.text:
I feel like genres are more
smashed together, I feel like...

153.16.text:
pop isn't as dirty of a word

Not that people weren't smiling

but it was definitely more like

and this year is way more like

I don't know, I just think that attitudes
and shifts change

176.04.text:
I'm also responding
to my environment in that way.

Seeing again the Chorus video and
the Home video, I was reminded of how

188.04.text:
I mean I like them both quite a bit
because Chorus, it's....

you know, you're inside the home,

there's products floating around,

of the laptop

and the signals

You know what I'm saying though,

and that's one thing that I find really

having some sort of agency

298.08.text: or in that kind of like fatalistic zone...

300.32.text:
I feel like in a way, that kind of is like

303.68.text:
it kinda like, you know,
takes the burden of us.

So I feel like we have to pair that with a

309.16.text:
and a degree of, kind of like,
forward propelling motion,

313.40.text:
so that we can actually have some sort

if you look back to the 60s, people are

and so, it's of course exciting to think

341.64.text:
contemporary art works' role and

you began with talking about the way in

this idea of like, the concept rule in the

if promoters know

the ways in which a sound can carry so

the way a sound carries a politic...

how to make that

super-embedded with all kinds of like

these new emotions that we're feeling

you know, like, for example, the piece on

we were both coming together, how can

966.40.text:

like, OK, I'm gonna let it go and then
